title: Bohemian Rhapsody's Lucy Boynton to star as 60s singer and Mick Jagger's lover Marianne Faithfull
text:
She played Freddie Mercury's lover Mary Austin in last year's Bohemian Rhapsody.

And now Lucy Boynton, 25, is set to star on the big screen as 1960s folk singer and Mick Jagger's girlfriend Marianne Faithfull, Deadline.com reported Thursday.

The British actress is also in talks to serve as an executive producer on the project which may go into production next summer.

New role: British actress Lucy Boynton, left, is reported to be in talks to star as folk singer and sixties icon Marianne Faithfull, right, in a new movie, Deadline.com reported Thursday

In addition to Bohemian Rhapsody, Boynton's film credits include Kenneth Branagh's Murder On The Orient Express and Rebel In The Rye.

Faithfull found fame after being discovered by Rolling Stones manager and record producer Andrew Loog Oldham when she attended a party for the band in 1964.

She was 17 when she recorded the song As Tears Go By, written and composed by Mick Jagger, Keith Richards and Oldham, and it became a hit in the UK when it was released in June 1964.

It went on to chart in the Billboard 100 in the US in November that year.

On the rise: Boynton, 25, came to prominence in Hollywood with her role as Freddie Mercury's lover Mary Austin in last year's Bohemian Rhapsody

Teen star: Faithfull, pictured in 1965, was 17 when she recorded her first hit single as Tears Go By which was written Mick Jagger, Keith Richards and Stones manager Andrew Loog Oldham

Couple: She embarked on a high-profile romance with Rolling Stones frontman Jagger and they epitomized the Swinging Sixties scene in London with their partying and drug use

Struggle: After splitting from Jagger in 1970, her professional and personal life went into a downward spiral as she battled addiction and anorexia and attempted suicide

Faithfull released several hit singles and in late 1966, shortly after giving birth to her son Nicholas in November 1965, she left her husband to live with Jagger.

Jagger and Faithfull epitomized the Swinging Sixties scene in London with their partying and drug use.

She is said to have inspired several Rolling Stones songs including Sympathy For The Devil, You Can't Always Get What you Want and Wild Horses.

She and Jagger split in 1970 and from then on, her professional and personal life went into a downward spiral.

She battled addiction, lost custody of her young son, attempted suicide and went on to marry and divorce two more times.

Faithfull continued to record and release albums and in 1999 ranked 25th on VH1's 100 Greatest Women of Rock and Roll.

Now 72, she lives in Paris and released her 21st studio album Negative Culpability in late 2018.
